title-group.article-title: Unveiling fungal detoxification pathways of the cruciferous phytoalexin rapalexin A: Sequential L-cysteine conjugation, acetylation and oxidative cyclization mediated by Colletotrichum spp.

kwd.tp:taxon-name: C. truncatum (Schwein.) Andrus & W. D. Moore

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Unveiling fungal detoxification pathways of the cruciferous phytoalexin rapalexin A : Sequential L-cysteine conjugation, acetylation and oxidative cyclization mediated by
Colletotrichum spp.
M. Soledade C. Pedras ∗ , Chintamani Thapa
Department of Chemistry , University of Saskatchewan , 110 Science Place , Saskatoon , SK, S7N 5C9, Canada
A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p:
C. lentis
crucifer
Detoxification Isothiocyanate Phytoalexin
Rapalexin A

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: A B S T R A C T

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
The metabolism of the phytoalexin rapalexin A , a unique indole isothiocyanate (ITC) produced by crucifers (family Brassicaceae ), was investigated. Three phytopathogenic fungal species were examined:
Colletotrichum dematium
(Pers.:Fr.) Grove, a broad host range pathogen,
C. higginsianum Sacc.
, a host-selective pathogen of crucifers and
C. lentis Damm
, a host-selective pathogen of lentils (
Lens culinaris Medik.
). The metabolism of rapalexin A by
C. dematium
and
C. higginsianum
was similar, taking place via one common intermediate and two divergent pathways, but
C. lentis
was unable to transform rapalexin A . Both
C. higginsianum
and
C. dematium
transformed rapalexin A to two previously undescribed metabolites, the structures of which were confirmed by chemical synthesis: N -acetyl-S-(8-methoxy-4
H
-thiazolo[5,4-b]indol-2-yl)-L-cysteine and 4-hydroxy-3-(4- methoxy-1
H
-indol-3-yl)-2-thioxothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid. That is, both fungal pathogens metabolized and detoxified rapalexin A by addition of the thiol group of L-Cys residue to the isothiocyanate carbon of rapalexin A , a transformation usually catalyzed by glutathione transferases. Coincidentally, this metabolic pathway is employed by mammals and insects to detoxify isothiocyanates and other xenobiotics. Hence,
C. higginsianum
could be a useful model fungus to uncover genes involved in the detoxification pathways of ITCs and related xenobiotics. Our overall results suggest that increasing rapalexin A production in specific crucifers could increase crop resistance to certain fungal pathogens.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
Cruciferous phytoalexins occupy a unique chemical space due to a variety of functional groups that contain distinct arrangements of carbon, nitrogen, oxygen and sulfur atoms in a relatively simple carbon skeleton (
). The phytoalexin rapalexin A ( 1 ) is in a unique position within this group of plant defenses in that, together with rapalexin B ( 1a ), are the first indolyl isothiocyanates (ITCs) reported from plants (
). Similar to other plants, crucifers under stress biosynthesize de novo antimicrobial metabolites known as phytoalexins, which are involved in fighting microbial invaders including phytopathogenic fungi (
). Stresses such as pathogen attack, UV radiation or heavy metals can elicit phytoalexins in different plant organs, e.g. leaves, stems or roots (
). Crucifers (order Brassicales , family Brassicaceae ) including broccoli (
Brassica oleracea var. italica
L.), cauliflower (
B. oleracea var. botrytis
L.), canola (
B. napus
L. and
B. rapa
L.) and brown mustard (
B. juncea
L.), are agronomically important crops cultivated
worldwide that produce rapalexin A ( 1 ).

Rapalexin A ( 1 ) resistance to detoxification by two economically important crucifer fungal pathogens suggests that increasing its biosynthesis in crucifer species could improve disease resistance levels to some pathogens. However, to understand the magnitude and implications of this resistance to detoxification, it is necessary to investigate additional phytopathogenic fungal species. Toward this end, because the genus
Colletotrichum
comprises fungal species with diverse host ranges (O'Connell et al., 2012;
), the transformation of rapalexin A ( 1 ) by three
Colletotrichum species
was studied: (i)
Colletotrichum dematium
(Pers.:Fr.) Grove, a generalist pathogen that infects a wide range of plant spp. (e.g. Madagascar periwinkle (
Catharanthus roseus
L., Apocynaceae ), spinach (
Spinacea oleracea
L., Amaranthaceae ), Japanese radish (
Raphanus sativus
L.
var. hortensis Baker
, Brassicaceae ), and berries) (
;
); (ii)
C. higginsianum Sacc.
, a host-selective pathogen and a model species (O'Connell et al., 2012) that infects crucifers causing anthracnose lesions on kimchi cabbage (
B. rapa var. glabra
), Chinese cabbage (
B. rapa L.
) and the model sp.
Arabidopsis thaliana
L. (
;
); (iii)
C. lentis Damm
(previously misidentified as
C. truncatum (Schwein.) Andrus & W. D. Moore
;
), a host-selective pathogen of lentils (
Lens culinaris Medik.
) that, similar to
C. dematium
and
C. higginsianum
, has a hemibiotrophic lifestyle (
). Previously,
Colletotrichum spp.
were employed for biotransformation of diverse compounds to identify potential synthetic and industrial applications of these reactions. In a few specific examples
Colletotrichum spp.
, as for example,
C. dematium
, were shown to detoxify phytoalexins of alfalfa (
Medicago sativa
) using hydroxylation or demethylation reactions (
).

Here we describe work uncovering the transformations of rapalexin A ( 1 ) mediated by
Colletotrichum spp.
and its detoxification by conjugation with L-cysteine (L-Cys) followed by acetylation and oxidative cyclization. Remarkably, although conjugation with L-Cys is a detoxification of xenobiotics common in animals and plants, to the best of our knowledge this is the first report of detoxification of a phytoalexin by conjugation with L-Cys.

sec.title:
2.1. Biotransformation of rapalexin A (1) and structure elucidation of
metabolites
sec.p:
First, to choose the concentration of rapalexin A ( 1 ) to use in biotransformation experiments, its inhibitory activity against
C. higginsianum , C. dematium
and
C. lentis
was determined as described in the experimental. Results of these bioassays indicated that rapalexin A ( 1 , 0.50–0.050 mM) is a mycelial growth inhibitor of the three
Colletotrichum species
, causing complete mycelial growth inhibition at 0.25 mM. Next, to establish potential biotransformation pathway(s) of rapalexin A ( 1 ), mycelial cultures of each fungal species were incubated with rapalexin A ( 1 ) in a chemically defined media (MM); samples were withdrawn from cultures immediately after addition of 1 (0.050 mM at zero hours) and then up to 96 h. Culture samples were either frozen or immediately subjected to neutral, acidic and basic extractions (EtOAc) to obtain more complete and consistent metabolite profiles, as detailed in the experimental, and the concentrated extracts were analyzed by HPLC-DAD-ESI-MS. Samples of MM incubated with 1 (control solutions) were extracted and analyzed similarly to determine its chemical stability and recovery. Similarly, samples of cultures of each species in MM were extracted and analyzed to evaluate metabolite production in the absence of rapalexin A ( 1 ) (control cultures).

The HPLC-DAD chromatograms of extracts of cultures of
C. dematium
and
C. higginsianum
incubated with rapalexin A indicated a decrease in rapalexin A ( 1 ) concentration up to 48 h, while no variation of concentration in cultures of
C. lentis
was observed. Importantly, however, it was observed that only the HPLC chromatograms of extracts of acidified cultures displayed a few small peaks that were not present in the chromatograms of acidified control cultures (i.e. all chromatograms of neutral extracts incubated with 1 were similar to those of control cultures). These results suggested that rapalexin A ( 1 ) was transformed by
C. dematium
and
C. higginsianum
to acidic metabolites and that
C. lentis
did not metabolize rapalexin A ( 1 ). The fairly fast transformation of 1 and the low intensity of the peaks observed in all chromatograms suggested that the transformation products were not soluble in the extraction solvent (EtOAc). Hence, recover these products from the fungal cultures, incubation experiments were carried out in water, as described in the Experimental Section 4.3. In brief,
C. dematium
and
C. higginsianum
were first grown in MM and the mycelial mats were washed and incubated with rapalexin A ( 1 ) in water; culture samples were collected immediately and then every 12 h, subjected to freeze-drying and the residue was analyzed by HPLC-DAD ( Fig. S1 ) and TIC-MS ( Fig. S2 ). Control cultures of mycelia in water were prepared and analyzed similarly.

The HPLC-DAD-ESI-MS chromatograms of cultures incubated with rapalexin A ( 1 ) displayed two peaks, not detected in the chromatograms of control cultures, with t
R
= 3.4 min ( 9 ) ( m/z 323.0, [M-1] - ) and tR = 7.1 min ( 5 ) ( m/z 366.0, [M+1] + ) and UV spectra different from that of rapalexin A ( 1 , m/z 203.0, [M-1] - ) ( Fig. S2 ). After 12 h of incubation the concentration of rapalexin A ( 1 ) decreased to less than 50% in cultures of
C. higginsianum
(t 1/2 = 4 h) and
C. dematium
(t 1/ 2 = 8 h); 1 was not detected in any of the cultures after 48 h. The component with tR = 7.1 min ( 5 ) appeared to be the major product of rapalexin A ( 1 ) metabolism in cultures of
C. dematium
, whereas the component with tR = 3.4 min ( 9 ) appeared to be the major product in cultures of
C. higginsianum
. To obtain sufficient amounts for spectroscopic characterization and structure elucidation of these unknown components ( 5 and 9 ), larger scale cultures were carried out as detailed in the Experimental Section 4.4. Eventually, the component with tR = 7.1 min ( 5 ) was obtained from cultures of
C. dematium
while the component with tR = 3.4 min ( 9 ) was obtained from cultures of
C. higginsianum
, as summarized below.

sec.title: 2.1.1. Compound 5 ( tR = 7.1 min)
sec.p:
Cultures of
C . dematium
in water were incubated with rapalexin A ( 1 ) for 36 h, filtered and the filtrate was freeze-dried. The freeze-dried residue was fractionated by column chromatography, as described in the experimental, to yield the purified compound with tR = 7.1 min ( 1.1 mg ). Consistent with the HPLC-MS chromatograms, the HRMS-ESI spectrum of this compound ( 5 ) displayed an ion at m/z 366.0248 [M + H ] + (positive ion mode) suggesting the molecular formula C 15 H 15 N 3 O 4 S 2 (ten degrees of unsaturation) that implied an addition of a C 5 H 6 NO 3 S unit to rapalexin A ( 1 ) (C 10 H 8 N 2 OS). The 1 H NMR spectrum ( Table 1 ) of this compound in CD 3 OD displayed eight resonances due to 12 protons, which together with its molecular formula indicated that the molecule contained three exchangeable protons. The coupling pattern of three aromatic protons ( δH 7.20, t, J = 8.0 Hz; 7.07 d, J = 8.0 Hz; 6.70, d, J = 8.0 Hz) together with the HMQC spectrum indicated that the proton at C-2 of the indole ring was absent. In addition, a spin system of three protons ( δH 3.70, dd, J = 13.5, 3.8 Hz; 3.51 dd, J = 13.5, 7.5 Hz; 4.55, dd, 7.5, 3.8 Hz) suggesting a – CH – CH 2 - unit with diastereomeric protons (HMQC, δC 56.7, CH , 41.4, CH 2 ), plus two methyl groups at δH 4.00 ( δC 56.0) and 1.89 ( δC 22.8) accounted for a total of 12 protons. The 13 C NMR spectrum ( Table 1 ) displayed the expected 15 carbon resonances, with two low field signals consistent with carbonyl carbons ( δC 176.3 and 173.0), plus five signals due to quaternary sp 2 carbons. The HMBC spectrum of this compound ( tR = 7.1 min) showed a correlation of the methyl protons at δH 1.89 with a low field carbon at δC 173.0 ppm, suggesting that this methyl was part of an acetyl group, whereas, the diastereotopic proton at δH 3.51 showed a correlation to the carbon at δC 154.6 ppm ( Fig. 3 ). Considering that this molecule had an index of hydrogen deficiency of ten and that the indole ring together with two carbonyl groups accounted for eight unsaturations, two additional unsaturations were assigned to an unsaturated heterocyclic ring. Reasoning that the C 5 H 6 NO 3 S unit added to rapalexin A ( 1 ) resulted from addition of N - acetyl-L-cysteine ( N -Ac-Cys) (C 5 H 9 NO 3 S) followed by oxidative cyclization, the additional unsaturated ring was assigned as a 1,3-thiazole, and the complete structure of the compound with tR = 7.1 min was assigned as N -acetyl- S -(8-methoxy-4H-thiazolo[5,4-b]indol-2-yl)-cysteine ( 5 ). This structure including the absolute configuration of C-11 ( R- ), was confirmed unambiguously by synthesis, as summarized below and described in the experimental section.

Surprisingly, to date no representatives of the heterocycle 1,4-dihydro-2
H
-thiazolo[5,4- b ]indole-2-thione ( 6 , C 9 H 6 N 2 S 2 , CAS Registry Number 1521001-96-6) or its tautomer 6a , the parent system of N - acetyl- S -(8-methoxy-4H-thiazolo[5,4-b]indol-2-yl)-L-cysteine ( 5 ), appear to have been reported. On the other hand, S -(2-benzothiazolyl)-Lcysteine ( 7 ) is a well-known synthetic compound used for detection of β-lyase activity (EC 4.4.1.13) (
).

Reasoning that compound 5 ( tR = 7.1 min) resulted from bioconjugation of rapalexin A ( 1 ) with N -acetyl-L-cysteine ( N -Ac-Cys), a biomimetic synthesis was explored. Initially, attempts to couple rapalexin A ( 1 ) with N -Ac-L-Cys under various conditions resulted in the recovery of both compounds, with no evidence of adduct formation. Presuming that the failure to obtain the adduct was caused by the low reactivity of the ITC carbon of 1 (due to the electron-donating effect of the indole ring), N -Boc rapalexin A was used. Under basic conditions, N - Boc rapalexin A reacted with N -Ac-L-Cys to yield adduct
8 in
good yield ( Fig. 4 ). Oxidative cyclization of 8 to form the thiazole ring was first attempted following a procedure similar to that reported for cyclobrassinin (using pyridinium bromide perbromide,
), but only traces of the thiazole product were detected among several other products. However, cyclization using N -bromosuccinimide yielded the thiazole product that after deprotection yielded the desired product
5 in
20% overall yield. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data and the HPLC tR and UV spectrum of this synthetic sample were identical to those of the isolated compound ( tR = 7.1 min); as well, the [α] D value of the synthetic sample 5 was similar to that of the isolated compound. These data confirmed the chemical structure and absolute configuration of the metabolite with tR = 7.1 min as N - acetyl-S -(8-methoxy-4H-thiazolo[5,4-b]indol-2-yl)-L-cysteine ( 5 ). To the best of our knowledge this is the first report of the synthesis of this novel heterocyclic ring.

sec.title: 2.1.2. Compound 9 ( tR = 3.4 min)
sec.p:
While the component with tR = 7.1 min ( 5 ) was obtained from cultures of
C . dematium
incubated with rapalexin A ( 1 ), as summarized above (Section 2.1.1), attempts to isolate the component with tR = 3.4 min ( 9 ) led to decomposition, yielding rapalexin A ( 1 ) and undetermined products. Hence, the isolation of 9 from cultures of
C. higginsianum
(where it was produced in larger amounts) was attempted. HPLC-HR-ESI-MS data of culture extracts suggested that this component resulted from conjugation of rapalexin A ( 1 ) with a cysteine derivative (ions at m/z 323.0161, calc. for C 13 H 11 N 2 O 4 S 2 , 323.0155, [M - H ] - and 118.9800, calc. for C 3 H 3 O 3 S, 118.9797). Anticipating to increase the production of this component, cultures of
C. higginsianum
were incubated with rapalexin A ( 1 ) and L-Cys or rapalexin A ( 1 ) and N -Ac-Cys and the appearance of peaks at tR = 3.4 min ( 9 ) and tR = 7.1 min ( 5 ) was monitored by HPLC-DAD-ESI-MS; the chromatograms indicated that both peaks increased in cultures containing L-Cys and rapalexin A ( 1 ) up to 24 h, but not in cultures containing N -Ac-Cys and rapalexin A ( 1 ) (which were similar to cultures containing only rapalexin A ( 1 )) ( Fig. 5 ). These peaks were not detected in the absence of mycelia of
C. higginsianum
or rapalexin A ( 1 ). Based on these results, cultures of
C. higginsianum
were incubated with rapalexin A ( 1 ) and L-Cys, filtered and the filtrate was freeze-dried. The freeze-dried filtrate residue was dissolved in different solvents and analyzed by HPLC to monitor the solubility and stability of the component at tR = 3.4 min ( 9 ). Results of these analyses indicated that the component at tR = 3.4 min ( 9 ) was soluble and moderately stable in water-acetonitrile. Subsequently, fractionation of the filtrate residue using flash column chromatography (FCC) led to the isolation of this component at tR = 3.4 min ( 9 ) ( 2.5 mg ). Although during this purification a slow decomposition to rapalexin A ( 1 ) was detected, the isolated compound was of sufficient purity to obtain the NMR spectroscopic data necessary to elucidate its structure (obtained in DMSO‑ d 6 and in D 2 O ).
*assignments may be interchanged.
++Major peak.
+minor peak.
The HR-MS-ESI spectrum of the compound with tR = 3.4 min ( 9 )

displayed an ion at m/z 323.0165 [M-H] - , suggesting the molecular formula C 13 H 12 N 2 O 4 S 2 (nine degrees of unsaturation) that implied the addition of a C 3 H 5 O 3 S unit to rapalexin A (C 10 H 8 N 2 OS). The 1 H NMR spectrum obtained in DMSO‑ d 6 ( Table 2 ) displayed several overlapping aromatic signals, unlike that of rapalexin A ( 1 ) (displayed two welldefined spin systems for the indole ring, i.e. H-5/H-6/H-7 and H-2/ N– H ). In addition to aromatic signals, the 1 H NMR spectrum of 9 displayed two sets of signals for several protons in a ca. 3:1 ratio; for example, two spin systems at δH 4.12, 3.05, (d, J = 11.0 Hz, 0.4 × 2 H ) and at δH 3.85, 3.15, (d, J = 11.0 Hz, 1.2 × 2 H ) indicated the presence of two groups of diastereomeric methylene protons in a 3:1 ratio ( Table 2 ). Similarly, the 13 C NMR spectrum in DMSO‑ d 6 ( Table 2 ) was complex, displaying more than the expected 13 resonances, with two very low field signals of different intensities, consistent with thiocarbonyl carbons ( δC 197.7 and 196.7, ca. 1:3), plus two signals assigned to carbonyl carbons ( δC 170.2 and 167.4, ca. 3:1) and several aromatic signals of various intensities. Altogether, the complex NMR spectra suggested that this polar compound was a mixture of two isomers. This hypothesis was consistent with the broadness of the corresponding peak observed in the HPLC chromatogram ( tR = 3.4 min).

By contrast, the 1 H NMR spectrum of this compound in D 2 O was somewhat simpler displaying six broad signals that integrated for nine protons (three exchangeable protons not detectable, C 13 H 12 N 2 O 4 S 2 ). In addition to the spin systems due to a 3,4-disubstituted indole nucleus containing a methoxy group ( δH 3.84, OCH 3 ), two broad doublets at δH 4.00 (1 H , d, 13.5 Hz) and δH 3.51 (1 H , d, 13.5 Hz) attached to a carbon at δC 38.9 (HMQC) were consistent with the presence of two diastereotopic methylene protons. Similarly, the 13 C NMR spectrum obtained in D 2 O was simpler than that obtained in DMSO‑ d 6 , displaying only nine carbon resonances, with a low field carbon at δC 201.6 corresponding to the thiocarbonyl carbon. However, the carbonyl carbon observed in DMSO‑ d 6 at δC 170.3 was not observed in D 2 O but was detectable through an HMBC correlation of the methylene proton at δH 3.51. At this point, a close inspection of the spectra obtained in D 2 O indicated some decomposition during spectral acquisition. Indeed, the signals corresponding to the methylene doublets at δΗ 4.00 and 3.51 were reduced substantially while the aromatic signals remained intact. These results confirmed that on standing this compound decomposed to rapalexin A ( 1 ) and undetermined products. Based on these extensive analyses of the spectroscopic data (DMSO‑ d 6 and D 2 O ) and HR-ESI-MS data, the structure of the compound with tR = 3.4 min is assigned as 4- hydroxy-3-(4-methoxy-1
H
-indol-3-yl)-2-thioxothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid ( 9 ). The double signals observed in the NMR spectra are assigned to rotamers that, relative to the NMR time scale, have a slower interconversion in DMSO‑ d 6 than in D 2 O . The main inferences taken from these results are summarized in Fig. 6 .

To ensure that this outcome was not due to execution of the published procedure but caused by the low stability of amine 14 , this reaction was repeated using benzylamine ( 15 ) and ethyl bromopyruvate, as previously reported (
) yielding the expected product ethyl 3-benzyl-4-hydroxy-2-thioxothiazolidine-4-carboxylate ( 17 , 74% yield, Fig. 9 ). However, similar conditions to prepare the corresponding carboxylic acid 12 using benzylamine ( 15 ) and bromopyruvic acid did not yield the desired product, instead the corresponding dehydrated product 3-benzyl-2-thioxo-2,3-dihydrothiazole-4-carboxylic acid ( 16 ) was obtained (45% yield). HPLC-DAD-ESI-MS analysis of the crude reaction mixture indicated that dehydration occurred mostly during purification of the product, regardless of the separation media used. For this reason, a procedure that afforded a product not requiring purification was devised by reacting near stoichiometric amounts of benzylamine ( 15 ), CS 2 and bromopyruvic acid, as described in the Experimental Section 4.6.3. Similar conditions employed to react 4- methoxyindole-3-amine ( 14) (unstable and always prepared in situ ) with CS 2 and bromopyruvic acid yielded a mixture that contained the desired thioxothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid ( 9 ) plus HNEt 3 Br, as determined by HPLC-DAD-ESI-MS and HRMS-ESI analyses and 1 H NMR spectroscopic analysis.

The HPLC-DAD-ESI-MS chromatogram of the crude reaction mixture displayed a peak with tR = 3.4 min (method A ) and an UV absorption spectrum identical to that of compound 9 , whereas the HPLC-ESI-MS spectrum negative mode ( Fig. S3 ) displayed ions at m/z 358.7, 359.8, 360.8, corresponding to dimers of HNEt 3 Br, and at m/z 322.7, corresponding to compound 9 . Fractionation of this reaction mixture yielded 9 together with HNEt 3 Br, in a rather low yield, that is partly attributed to the relatively lower stability of both the intermediate (4- methoxyindole-3-amine ( 14) ) and the desired product 9 .

sec.title: 2.2. Biotransformation of N-acetyl-S-(8-methoxy-4H-thiazolo[5,4-b]indol-2-yl)cysteine (5) and antifungal activity
sec.p:
C. dematium
and
C. higginsianum
transformed rapalexin A to N - acetyl- S -(8-methoxy-4
H
-thiazolo[5,4-b]indol-2-yl)cysteine ( 5 ) and to 4- hydroxy-3-(4-methoxy-1
H
-indol-3-yl)-2-thioxothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid ( 9 ). To establish if metabolite 5 was further metabolized, 5 was administered separately to cultures of
C. dematium
and
C. higginsianum
in water and cultures treated and analyzed as described above for rapalexin A ( 1 ). Comparison of the HPLC-DAD-ESI-MS chromatograms of cultures incubated with 5 and control solutions incubated with 5 , suggested that both
C. dematium
and
C. higginsianum
metabolize N - acetyl- S -(8-methoxy-4
H
-thiazolo[5,4-b]indol-2-yl)cysteine ( 5 ) in ca. 48 h, since 5 remained unchanged in control solutions for the duration of the experiment. However, because no metabolic products of this transformation were detected, it is likely that multiple products were formed in low concentration. Metabolite 9 was not evaluated due to its low stability and decomposition to rapalexin A ( 1 ) in aqueous solutions.

The antifungal activity of rapalexin A ( 1 ), metabolite 5 and benzylisothiocyanate ( 11 ) was determined against
C. dematium
and
C. higginsianum
employing the radial mycelial grown assay described in the experimental. The antifungal activity was measured at 0.50, 0.25, 0.010 and 0.050 mM; the results indicated that 5 displayed significantly lower growth inhibitory activity than rapalexin A ( 1 ) ( Table 3 ), confirming that this transformation is a detoxification process. While rapalexin A ( 1 ) inhibited completely the growth of both
C. dematium
and
C. higginsianum
at 0.25 mM, metabolite 5 inhibited the growth for
C. dematium
and
C. higginsianum
by 15% and 43%, respectively, at similar concentration ( Table 3 ). The antifungal activity of metabolite 9 could not be measured due to decomposition. Overall, benzylisothiocyanate (11) was less inhibitory than rapalexin A (1).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Table 3

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Antifungal activity of rapalexin A ( 1 ) and N -acetyl- S -(8-methoxy-4H-thiazolo [5,4-b]indol-2-yl)cysteine ( 5 , tR = 7.1 min) and benzylisothiocyanate ( 11 ) against
Colletotrichum species.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: a Percentage of growth inhibition calculated using the formula: % inhibition = 100 - [(growth on amended medium/growth on control medium) × 100]; values are averages of at least two independent experiments conducted in triplicate. Superscript letters in the same row (b - g) indicate significant differences (p <0.05) in one-way ANOVA analysis; n.i. = no inhibition.

sec.title: 3. Discussion and conclusion
sec.p:
Our previous work has shown that rapalexin A ( 1 ) displays resistance to metabolism by two host-selective crucifer pathogens (
L. maculans
and
A. brassicicola
), a necessary attribute for effective plant protection (
). To understand further this resistance to metabolism, we investigated the transformation of rapalexin A ( 1 ) by three
Colletotrichum species
having different host-ranges,
C. dematium
, a broad host range pathogen that infects various plant families,
C. higginsian
um a crucifer pathogen and a model fungus for studying fungal pathogenicity and plant immune responses, and
C. lentis
, a host-selective pathogen of lentils. Both
C. higginsianum
and
C. dematium
were able to transform rapalexin A ( 1 ) to two previously undescribed metabolites: N -acetyl-S-(8-methoxy-4H-thiazolo[5,4-b] indol-2-yl)cysteine ( 5 ) and 4-hydroxy-3-(4-methoxy-1
H
-indol-3-yl)-2- thioxothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid ( 9 ). These compounds possess unique structures and in particular, thiazoloindole 5 is the first member of the previously unknow heterocyclic system 1,4-dihydro-2
H
-thiazolo [5,4- b ]indole-2-thione ( 6 / 6a ). Although the chemical structure of metabolite 5 suggested that it could result from S -conjugation of rapalexin A ( 1 ) with N -acetyl-L-Cys, our results indicate that formation of metabolites 5 and 9 is likely to result from S -conjugation of rapalexin A ( 1 ) with L-Cys (only experiments using L-Cys increased production of 5 and 9 ). Furthermore, it is well-known that biological ITC– S -Cys conjugates result from reactions of electrophilic ITCs with glutathione (GSH), which in general are catalyzed by glutathione transferases (GSTs) (
). Hence, integration of this knowledge with our results, leads us to propose one common intermediate and two divergent pathways for the transformation of rapalexin A ( 1 ) by
C. dematium
and
C. higginsianum
( Fig. 10 ). In both pathways A and B , the thiol group of GSH adds to the electrophilic ITC carbon of rapalexin A ( 1 ) to yield an intermediate that is successively hydrolyzed to release first L-Glu and then Gly to yield the L-Cys-conjugate 18 . Next, in pathway A , intermediate 18 undergoes acetylation to produce the N - acetyl-L-Cys metabolite 19 that is oxidatively cyclized via potential intermediate 19a to yield metabolite 5 . This oxidative cyclization to form a thiazolo-indole ring appears to be the first report of such a biological reaction ( Fig. 10 ). In the parallel pathway B , intermediate 18 is first transaminated to 10 that undergoes cyclization to yield 9 . It is not clear if cyclization of 10 to 9 is enzymatic or spontaneous. Regardless, these results indicate that pathway A is more efficient at getting rid of rapalexin A ( 1 ) by detoxification, as 9 , the product of pathway B , decomposes spontaneously to yield back intact rapalexin A ( 1 ) ( Fig. 10 ).

Overall, our metabolism experiments suggest that
C. dematium
follows mainly pathway A , hence we infer that this pathogen detoxifies rapalexin A ( 1 ) more efficiently than
C. higginsianum
(mainly pathway B ), although rapalexin A is not detected in either case after 48 h. Rapalexin A is produced in various
Brassica spp.
and other crucifers (
), but is unlikely to be produced by most of the plant spp. that host
C. dematium
. For this reason and based on related work (reviewed in
), it was expected that detoxification of rapalexin A ( 1 ) by a crucifer pathogen (
C. higginsianum
) would be different from a generalist pathogen
( C. dematium
). Yet, our results demonstrate the formation of identical products, hence it is suggested that the enzymes mediating rapalexin A detoxification in both
C. higginsianum
and
C. dematium
are house-keeping enzymes involved in the detoxification of ITCs (and perhaps other electrophilic xenobiotics). Alternatively,
C. higginsianum
could produce selective enzyme(s) involved in rapalexin A detoxification, similar to another host-selective fungal spp. (e.g. brassinin and
L. maculans
or
A. brassicicola
). In addition, it is pertinent to point out that these results are consistent with the fact that
C. higginsianum
and
C. dematium
are phylogenetically close species (located in adjacent clades), whereas
C. lentis
is located in a more distant clade (
).

It is noteworthy that both
C. higginsianum
and
C. dematium
were able to detoxify rapalexin A ( 1 ) using a pathway common to mammals and insects ( S -conjugation with L-Cys and glutathione). Hence, given the availability of the genome sequences of
C. higginsianum
, this fungus could be a useful model to uncover genes involved in the detoxification pathways of ITCs and other xenobiotics. Although
C. lentis
was not able to metabolize rapalexin A ( 1 ), this is not surprising considering its narrow host range (lentils) and that lentils belong to a species phylogenetically distant from
Brassica spp.
This interpretation is consistent with our previous work showing that phytoalexin detoxifying enzymes isolated from host-selective fungi displayed a narrow substrate range, whereas a detoxifying enzyme from a broad host range species had a broader substrate range (
). Considering the strong inhibitory activity of rapalexin A ( 1 ) against several phytopathogenic fungal species, including
C. higginsianum
and
C. dematium ,
and resistance to metabolism by
L. maculans
and
A. brassicicola ,
increasing its production in specific crucifer crops could increase resistance to some fungal pathogens. In this context, it would be valuable to establish the role of the GSTs of
C. higginsianum
in causing virulence in crucifer species, similar to work carried out with
A. brassicicola ( Calmes et al., 2015 )
.

Finally, it appears appropriate to emphasize that the investigation of phytoalexin detoxification reactions can assist in understanding the interactions of plants with their pathogens and lead the development of associated disease protection strategies.

sec.title: 4.1. General
sec.p: All solvents were HPLC grade and used as such; unless otherwise noted, materials were obtained from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. Flash column chromatography (FCC): silica gel, grade 60, 230–400 μm, Sephadex LH-20, or RP C-18. Organic extracts were dried over Na 2 SO 4 and the solvents were removed using a rotary evaporator.

NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance spectrometers. For 1 H NMR (500 or 600 MHz) and 13 C NMR (125.8 or 150.9 MHz) spectra, the chemical shifts (δ) are reported in parts per million (ppm) relative to TMS. MS data [high resolution (HR) were obtained on a Jeol AccuToF GCv 4 G mass spectrometer [field desorption (FD)] or on a Qstar XL MS/MS System (ESI) by direct insertion. Specific optical rotations [α] D were determined at ambient temperature on a Digipol DP781 polarimeter (Rudolph Instruments, Inc.) using a 1 mL, 10 cm path length cell; the units are 10 −1 deg cm
2 g
−1 and the concentrations ( c ) are reported in g/100 mL (averages of five measurements).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 4.2. HPLC analyses

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: HPLC-DAD analysis was carried out with Agilent 1100 and 1200 series systems all equipped with quaternary pump, autosampler, diode array detector (DAD, wavelength range 190–600 nm ), and degasser. Method A used a Zorbax Eclipse XDB-C-18 column (3.5 μm particle size silica, 100 × 3.0 mm I.D.), equipped with an in-line filter, with the mobile phase H 2 O– CH 3 OH from 70:30 to 0:100, linear gradient for 25 min, and a flow rate of 0.40 mL/min. Method B used a Zorbax Eclipse XDB-C-18 column (5 μm particle size silica, 150 × 2.1 mm I.D.), equipped with an in-line filter, with the mobile phase H 2 O– CH 3 CN from 100:0 to 10:90, linear gradient for 23 min, and a flow rate of 0.40 mL/ min.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: HPLC-DAD-ESI-MS analysis was carried out with an Agilent 1100 series HPLC system equipped with an autosampler, binary pump, degasser, and a diode array detector connected directly to a mass detector (Agilent G2440A MSD-Trap-XCT ion trap mass spectrometer) with an electrospray ionization (ESI) source. Chromatographic separations were carried out at room temperature using an Eclipse XDB-C-18 column (5 μm particle size silica, 150 mm × 4.6 mm I.D.). The mobile phase consisted of a linear gradient of H 2 O (with 0.2% HCO 2 H) – CH 3 CN (with 0.2% HCO 2 H) from 75:25 to 25: 75 in 25 min and a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min. Data acquisition was carried out in positive and negative polarity modes in a single LC run, and data processing carried out with Agilent Chemstation Software.

sec.title: 4.3. Fungal isolates, cultures and metabolism experiments
sec.p:
The three species used in this work are:
C. higginsianum Sacc.
(IMI 349061, CABI Culture Collection, https://www.cabi.org/services/ microbial-services/culture-collection-microorganism-supply/grc/);
C. dematium
(UAMH 6728, University of Alberta Microfungus Collection and Herbarium, Edmonton, Canada );
C. lentis
(DAOM 235316 = CT21, DAOM: Plant Research Institute, Department of Agriculture (Mycology), Ottawa, Canada ). Each species was grown on potato dextrose agar (PDA) plates at room temperature (23 ± 1 °C) under continuous light for four weeks and spores were collected, washed and counted under a compound microscope. Spores were stored in Eppendorf tubes in an aq glycerol solution (30%, v/v) at −80 °C.

Cultures of
Colletotrichum spp.
were initiated by inoculating fungal spores (10 6 spores per 100 mL) in 250 mL Erlenmeyer flasks containing minimal medium (MM) (
). After incubation (4 days for
C. dematium
, 5 days for
C. higginsianum
and
C. lentis
) at rt (23 ± 1 °C) under continuous light, in a shaker (110 rpm), a solution of rapalexin A ( 1 ) (0.050 mM) in CH 3 CN was added to each culture and culture samples were collected immediately and then every 12 h. The culture samples were first extracted with EtOAc (neutral extract), and the remaining aqueous phase was acidified to pH 2 (2 M HCl) and reextracted with Et 2 O to provide the acidic extract, and lastly the aqueous phase was basified (2 M NaOH) and reextracted with CHCl 3 to provide the basic extract; each extract was concentrated, dissolved in CH 3 CN and analyzed by HPLC-DAD-ESI-MS. Two different sets of controls were prepared as well, one contained media, fungal mycelia and CH 3 CN and the second control containing media and rapalexin A ( 1 ). All experiments were conducted in triplicate and were repeated at least twice (i.e. providing a minimum of 6 replicates).

To study the transformation in water, mycelia were incubated first in MM (4 days for
C. dematium
, 5 days for
C. higginsianum
and
C. lentis
), and then the cultures were filtered, the mycelial mass was washed multiple times with water under aseptic conditions and transferred to 250 mL Erlenmeyer flasks containing 100 mL of distilled water. Rapalexin A ( 1 ) (0.050 mM) was added to each culture and the cultures treated as reported above, including controls. Culture samples were freeze-dried, dissolved in CH 3 CN – H 2 O (60:40) and analyzed by HPLC-DAD-ESI-MS. The experiments were conducted in triplicate and were repeated at least twice.

sec.title: 4.4.1. Metabolite 5 ( tR = 7.1 min)
sec.p:
Cultures of
C. dematium
(20 Erlenmeyer flasks, 100 mL per flask) were initiated by inoculating fungal spores (10 6 spores per 100 mL) in MM at room temperature (23 ± 1 °C) under continuous light, in a shaker (110 rpm). After four days, cultures were filtered, and the mycelia were washed with sterilized distilled water and transferred to 250 mL Erlenmeyer flask containing sterilized distilled water (100 mL). A solution of rapalexin A ( 1 ) (3.0 mg/100 μL) in CH 3 CN was added to each culture flask. After 36 h, the cultures were filtered, the filtrate was freeze-dried to yield a crude residue ( 605 mg ). The crude residue was dissolved in H 2 O – CH 3 CN (80:20) and subjected to FCC on reverse phase RP C-18 eluted with H 2 O – CH 3 CN (80:20). Eight fractions (15 mL/ fraction) were collected and analyzed by HPLC-DAD-ESI-MS; the metabolite with tR = 7.1 min was present in F-3. After removal of CH 3 CN the aqueous phase was freeze-dried and F-3 was further separated using RP C-18 eluted with H 2 O – CH 3 CN (50:50). The final purification was carried out using RP C-18 eluted with H 2 O –MeOH (70:30) to yield the metabolite with tR = 7.1 min ( 1.1 mg ).

N-acetyl-S-(8-methoxy-4H-thiazolo[5,4-b]indol- 2-yl )cysteine (5). HPLC t R = 7.1 min (method A ). [α] D = −140 ( c = 0.010, MeOH). 1 H NMR (600 MHz, CD 3 OD) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, CD 3 OD) Table 1 . HR-ESI-MS m / z (%): calc. for C 15 H 15 N 3 O 4 S 2 , 366.0240, found m/z 366.0248 [M + H ] + (100). UV ( HPLC , CH 3 CN – H 2 O ) λ max : 220, 254, 280, 330 nm . FTIR (KBr) ν max : 3286, 2921, 1709, 1509, 1030 cm −1 .

sec.title: 4.4.2. Isolation of metabolite 9 ( tR = 3.4 min)
sec.p:
Cultures of
C. higginsianum
(10 6 spores/100 mL) were prepared in water as reported above for
C. dematium
using a total of 30 flasks. Rapalexin A (3.0 mg/100 μL) and L-Cys ( 3.6 mg /100 mL) were added to the cultures of
C. higginsianum
, the cultures were incubated for 24 h, were filtered and the filtrate was freeze-dried to yield a solid residue ( 700 mg ). The crude residue was fractionated using first Sephadex LH-20 eluted with H 2 O – CH 3 CN (60:40) to give six fractions; F-3 contained the metabolite with tR = 3.4 min. F-3 was further fractionated using RP C-18 and H 2 O – CH 3 CN (20:80) to give 11 fractions, with F-3–F-5 containing the metabolite with tR = 3.4 min ( 2.5 mg ).

4-Hydroxy-3(4-methoxy-1H-indol- 3-yl )-2-thioxothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid (9). HPLC t R = 3.4 min (method A ). For 1 H NMR (600 MHz, D 2 O and DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, D 2 O and DMSO‑ d 6 ) see Table 2 . HR-ESI-MS m / z (%): calc. for C 13 H 11 N 2 O 4 S 2 : 323.0155, found 323.0161 [M - H ] - . UV ( HPLC , CH 3 CN – H 2 O ) λ max : 220, 254, 280 nm .

sec.title: 4.5. Antifungal bioassays
sec.p:
The antifungal activity of each compound against
Colletotrichum species
was determined using a radial growth inhibition bioassay carried out on 12 well sterilized plates. A solution of the compound to be tested dissolved in CH 3 CN was uniformly mixed with warm PDA (0.50, 0.25, 0.10 and 0.050 mM) and plates allowed to cool. Mycelial plugs of 4 mm diameter were cut from the edge of PDA cultures of
Colletotrichum species
(5 days for
C. dematium
, 7 days for
C. higginsianum
and
C. lentis
) at 23 ± 1 °C under continuous light condition) and were placed upside down to the center of each well and incubated under constant light. Mycelial growth inhibition in each well was measured and percent inhibition was calculated using the formulae: % inhibition = 100- [(growth on mended/growth in control) X 100]. All experiments were carried out in triplicates and were repeated at least twice.

sec.title: 4.6.1. Synthesis of metabolite 5 ( tR = 7.1 min)
sec.p: N,N -Dimethyl-4-aminopyridine (DMAP, ca. 2 mg ) was added to a solution of rapalexin A ( 1 , 80 mg , 0.39 mmol) in tetrahydrofuran (THF, 4 mL) at rt, followed by di- tert -butyl dicarbonate ( 85 mg , 0.39 mmol). After 1 h the reaction mixture was diluted with water (5 mL) and extracted with EtOAc. The combined organic layer was dried, concentrated and the residue was subjected to FCC (EtOAC-hexane, 3:7) to yield tert -butyl 3-isothiocyanato-4-methoxy-1H-indole-1-carboxylate ( 100 mg , 0.32 mmol, 84%). A solution of N -acetyl-L-Cys ( 62 mg , 0.38 mmol) and NaHCO 3 ( 16 mg , 0.19 mmol) in EtOH– H 2 O (8:2, 1.5 mL) was slowly added to a solution of tert -butyl 3-isothiocyanato-4- methoxy-1H-indole-1-carboxylate ( 57 mg , 0.19 mmol) in THF (950 μL) at rt. The reaction mixture was heated to 60 °C and after 6 h was diluted with water (20 mL) and extracted with EtOAc. The combined organic layer was dried, concentrated and the residue was subjected to FCC (DCM-MeOH-AcOH, 90:10:1) to yield 2-acetamido-3-(((1-( tert -butoxycarbonyl)-4-methoxy-1H-indol-3yl)carbamothioyl)thio)propanoic acid ( 8 , 70 mg , 0.15 mmol, 80%).

N -bromosuccinimide (NBS) was added to compound 8 ( 60 mg , 0.13 mmol) in THF (2.0 mL) at rt. After stirring for 2 h, Et 3 N was added to the reaction mixture followed by further stirring. After 2 h, the solvent was evaporated, and the residue was subjected to FCC (DCMMeOH-AcOH, 90:10:1) to yield 2-acetamido-3-((4-( tert -butoxycarbonyl)-8-methoxy-4
H
-thiazolo[5,4-b]indol-2-yl)thio)propanoic acid ( 55 mg , 0.12 mmol, 93%). This compound ( 50 mg , 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in 20% trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) in DCM and stirred at room temperature for 8 h. The solvent was evaporated, and the residue was subjected to FCC (DCM-MeOH-AcOH, 90:10:1) to yield N -acetyl- S -(8- methoxy-4
H
-thiazolo[5,4-b]indol-2-yl)-L-cysteine ( 34 mg , 0.092 mmol, 86%). All spectroscopic data of this synthetic material were identical to those of metabolite 5 , except for the optical rotation ([α] D −190, c = 0.010, MeOH, slightly higher than that of the compound isolated from cultures ([α] D −140, c = 0.010, MeOH).

sec.title: 4.6.2. Synthesis of metabolite 9 ( tR = 3.4 min)
sec.p: In situ preparation of 4-methoxy-3-indoleamine ( 14 ). Pd/C ( 20 mg ) was added to a solution of 4-methoxy-3-nitroindole ( 13 , 0.10 mmol, 20 mg ) in THF (0.80 mL) and EtOH (160 μL) and the reaction mixture was stirred under hydrogen (balloon pressure). After 3 h, CS 2 (180 μL, 3.0 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture, the hydrogen balloon was removed, and stirring was continued for 5 min. A solution of bromopyruvic acid ( 12 mg , 0.07 mmol) in CH 3 CN (200 μL) and Et 3 N (11 μL, 0.11 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture and stirring continued for 45 min. The reaction mixture was filtered through celite and concentrated. The crude reaction mixture was analyzed by HPLC-DAD-ESI-MS, which indicated a mixture of products, including the desired product at tR = 3.4 min ( 9 ) ( Fig. S3 ). This crude reaction mixture was subjected to chromatography (Sephadex LH-20, H 2 O – CH 3 CN , 2:3) to yield 4-hydroxy-3-(4-methoxy-1H-indol-3-yl)-2-thioxothiazolidine-4- carboxylic acid (9) (ca. 1 mg ) together with HNEt 3 Br. HPLC : tR = 3.4 min (method A ). 1 H NMR (600 MHz, D 2 O ): δH 7. 22 (m, 2 H ), 7.17 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1 H ), 6.72 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1 H ), 4.00 (d, J = 13.5 Hz, 1 H ), 3.91 (s, 3 H ), 3.57 (d, J = 13.5 Hz, 1 H ). HR-ESI-MS ( m/z ): calc. for C 13 H 11 N 2 O 4 S 2 324.0165 [M - H ] - , found 323.0158. UV ( HPLC , CH 3 CN – H 2 O ) λ max : 220, 280 nm .

sec.title: 4.6.3. Synthesis of 3-benzyl-4-hydroxy-2-thioxothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid (12)
sec.p: CS 2 (38 μL, 0.33 mmol) was added to a solution of benzylamine ( 15 ) (36 μL, 0.33 mmol) in CH 3 CN (800 μL) at rt; after stirring for 10 min, a solution of bromopyruvic acid ( 50 mg , 0.30 mmol) and Et 3 N (62 μL, 0.45 mmol) in CH 3 CN (800 μL) was added to the reaction mixture and stirring was continued at rt. After 45 min, the reaction mixture was diluted with H 2 O (5 mL) and was extracted with CD 2 Cl 2 . The combined organic layer was dried and concentrated to yield a residue consisting of 12 and − Br + HN( CH 2 CH 3 ) 3 (1.5:1, by 1 H NMR). HPLC : tR = 4.0 min (method B ), 1 H NMR (500 MHz, CD 3 CN ): δH 10.76 (br s, 1 H ), 7.33 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 2 H ), 7.26 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 2 H ), 7.20 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1 H ), 4.90 (d, J = 15.5 Hz, 1 H ), 4.68 (d, J = 15.5 Hz, 1 H ), 3.89 (d, J = 11.5 Hz, 1 H ), 3.24 (d, J = 11.5 Hz, 1 H ). 13 C NMR (125.8 MHZ, CD 3 CN ) δC 199.2, 172.7, 138.2, 129.2, 129.0, 128.0, 99.4, 50.3, 39.7. HR-ESI-MS ( m/z ): calc. for C 11 H 10 NO 3 S 2 268.0108 [M - H ] - , found 268.0108. UV ( HPLC , CH 3 CN – H 2 O ) λ max : 220, 280 nm .

sec.title: 4.6.4. Synthesis of 3-benzyl-2-thioxo-2,3-dihydrothiazole-4-carboxylic acid
sec.p: CS 2 (150 μL, 2.45 mmol) was added to a solution of benzylamine ( 15 ) (50 μL, 0.49 mmol) in CH 3 CN (0.50 mL) at rt and after stirring for 60 min a solution of bromopyruvic acid ( 82 mg , 0.49 mmol) in CH 3 CN (0.30 mL) was added to the reaction mixture followed by addition of Et 3 N (140 μL, 0.98 mmol). Stirring was continued at rt and after 60 min, the reaction mixture was diluted with H 2 O (5 mL) and the pH was adjusted to 4 using a 2 M HCl solution. The aqueous phase was extracted with EtOAc, the combined organic layer was dried and concentrated to yield a residue ( 126 mg ). The residue was subjected to FCC - RP C-18 and eluted with H 2 O – CH 3 CN gradient (100:0 to 50:50) to yield 3-benzyl-2-thioxo-2,3-dihydrothiazole-4-carboxylic acid ( 16 ) in 45% yield ( 55 mg ).

sec.title: 4.6.5. Synthesis of ethyl 3-benzyl-4-hydroxy-2-thioxothiazolidine-4- carboxylate (17)
sec.p: CS 2 (550 μL, 9.2 mmol) was added to a solution of benzylamine ( 15 ) (100 μL, 0.92 mmol) and Et 3 N (130 μL, 0.92 mmol) in CH 3 CN (3.0 mL) at rt and after stirring for 30 min, a solution of ethyl bromopyruvate (115 μL, 0.92 mmol) in CH 3 CN (0.30 mL) was added to the reaction mixture followed by addition of and Et 3 N (260 μL, 1.82 mmol) and the reaction mixture was stirred at rt; after 30 min the reaction mixture was diluted with water (10 mL) and neutralized (HCl 2 M). The aqueous phase was extracted with EtOAc, concentrated and the crude mixture was subjected to FCC (EtOAc-hexane, 3:7) to yield ethyl 3-benzyl-4- hydroxy-2-thioxothiazolidine-4-carboxylate ( 17 ) ( 194 mg , 0.65 mmol) in 74% yield.
Acknowledgment

Financial support for the authors’ work was obtained from the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (Discovery Grant to M.S.C.P.), the Canada Research Chairs program, Canada Foundation for Innovation, the Saskatchewan Government, and the University of Saskatchewan (graduate assistantships to CT). We acknowledge the technical assistance of K. Thoms (MS) from the Department of Chemistry and the Saskatchewan Structural Sciences Centre.
